awd_titl_txt: PREM: Collaborative Research and Education in Energy Materials (CREEM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University is a large public HBCU and leads the nation in numbers of undergraduate, masters, and doctoral engineering degrees awarded to African Americans. The University is also the leading producer of African American female engineers at the baccalaureate level. The aim of the NSF Partnership for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) between NCAT and the Cornell Center of Materials Research (CCMR), an NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at Cornell University is to broaden the participation of underrepresented minority (URM) students and faculty members in renewable energy research and to create opportunities for graduate studies in materials research at NCAT and Cornell.  Providing clean and renewable energy is among the most critical challenges of the 21st century. Overcoming the energy challenge requires new conversion technologies that can meet the growing global energy demand. This PREM includes innovative concepts to increase the participation of URM students in materials research such as reciprocal exchange of students and faculty members, development of new courses in the field of energy, creation of research opportunities for K-16 students/teachers, and keeping the public informed about the advances in materials research and technology.

The NCAT-CCMR PREM seed team has formulated a research plan to develop low-dimensional (LD) titanium oxynitride (TiNO)-based materials capable of supporting energy conversion reactions. The project will also develop a fundamental understanding of materials’ physical and chemical properties across different length scales. The attraction of TiNO over more widely studied transition metal oxides is rooted in the polarizability, electronegativity, and anion charge of nitrogen versus that of oxygen, which induces an enormous change in the physical and chemical properties of the resulting compounds. The LD material research begins with a baseline thin-film synthesis, advancing to the more complicated synthesis of zero-and one-dimensional structures of titanium oxynitrides. Controlled modification in the electronic structure of the titanium oxynitride realized by changing the oxygen content as well as by manipulating its geometry and size will allow the production of materials with tunable conductivity and energy gap. The proposed research will establish the effectiveness of thin film-based methods for the synthesis of TiNO materials in epitaxial 2D, 1D, and 0D geometries. The convenience of making TiNO multilayers by merely changing the oxygen pressure during the growth, with each layer differing in the oxygen content and consequently bandgap, may prove to be a gateway capability in the fabrication of TiNO thin-film devices free from any organic layers for visible-light-harvesting applications. Dissemination of both research and education findings of the PREM seed project will involve open-access and traditional journals, conferences and a strong social media presence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION IN ENERGY MATERIALS (CREEM)

 

The NCAT-Cornell PREM partnership was established in 2021 via the PREM SEED award for three years. Broadening the participation of underrepresented minority (URM) students, postdoctoral fellows, and faculty members in materials research was the driving goal of the PREM seed project. The project used one of the most significant issues of our era, the renewable energy challenge, as a gateway to attract the URM population to materials research. This was achieved through a diverse team of scientists, engineers, and education experts from North Carolina Agricultural and Technical (NCAT) State University and the NSF MRSEC at Cornell University, the Cornell Center for Materials Research (CCMR). The reciprocal exchange of PREM and MRSEC faculty members, students, and postdoctoral fellows was the motivating force of this partnership toward increasing the quantity and quality of URM materials research at both institutions.

Executing a synergistically developed research plan, the NCAT-Cornell PREM partnership was successful in designing and synthesizing a transition metal (TM) based oxynitride (TMON) homolog series in thin film form using a pulsed laser deposition method. The TMON homolog series is capable of supporting energy conversion reactions and serves as a platform to gain an understanding of materials’ fundamental physical and chemical properties across different length scales. During the project, a series of epitaxial TiN/TiNO thin films with a controlled oxidation process was synthesized. Three methods of TiN oxidation were developed based on (i) the intentional addition of oxygen at different pressures, (ii) controlling the oxidation by varying the deposition time and temperature during film growth in the presence of residual oxygen, and (iii) controlling the oxidation by adding a non-oxidizing nitrogen gas during the film formation. Tailoring the properties of the TiNO system via controlled oxidation has an energy advantage over the conventional method of bandgap engineering of TiO2 via nitridation. The energy advantage comes from the higher activation energy of the nitridation process (672 kJ/mol) than that of the oxidation process (496 kJ/mol). The oxidation of TiN films affects the lattice constants of the TiON as predicted by molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and supported by x-ray diffraction measurements. The bandgap of TiN and TiON films, measured using UV-visible spectroscopy, has an asymmetric V-shape variation as a function of the number of pulses. The bandgap variation following the lower number of laser pulses (150-750) of the V-shaped curve is explained using the quantum confinement effect, while the bandgap variation following the higher number of laser pulses (1000-5000) is associated with the modification in the band structure due to hybridization of O2p and N2p energy levels. 

The computational modeling work on the electronic properties of titanium oxynitride systems has led to the foundation of the electronic band structure of TMONs that opens the pathway for tailoring the plasmonic and optical response in TMON-based materials. Using a novel on-site lattice substitution method for structure generation and calculations of the band gap; this study has demonstrated how the electronic density of states and consequently,  the electronic properties of TiNO are affected by an alteration in N/O composition of the structural models. Our findings on the optical and plasmonic properties of high electron density epitaxial and oxidative controlled titanium nitride thin films are also remarkable. We were able to make TiNO films with very high low-frequency reflectance (~90%), low dielectric losses, a large negative dielectric constant (~ 150), and a very high frequency (54,000 cm-1 ≡ 6.69 eV) of zero-crossing, which is the upper limit for use as plasmonic materials.

The availability of preeminent researchers and the world-class scientific infrastructure of the Cornell MRSEC, along with culturally responsive mentoring, also propelled the students to progress successfully along the PREM pathway. A large percentage of PREM students, after graduation, have already started the next step in their career path. The successes in building and sustaining the NCAT-Cornell PRM pathway are evident from the PREM key performance parameters in terms of (i) Recruitment: 17 graduate students, 16 undergraduate students, High School students: 4, High School teacher:1, (ii) Retention at all levels: 100 %, and (iii) Degree Attainment: Graduate students: 9, Undergraduate students: 9, High School students: 3 (iv) Science, fostering cutting-edge research: Presentations in local, national, international conferences: 52,  High Impact Publications: 15, Feature Articles in JAP and ACS, and (v) Partnership between MSI and leading research centers/facilities/platforms: joint workshops, joint courses/modules, and joint thesis/dissertation committees. The NCAT-Cornell PREM research and educational accomplishments and the research infrastructure established with the help of the PREM seed project have led to the successful funding of a $10.3 M four-year DOE-Energy Frontier Research Center and $4.2 M six-year NSF full PREM at North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University.
